Finally, when you create a module a line is added to the file ''./src/app/app.module.ts'. This line should looks like this 'import {<name-component>Component} from './<name-component>/<name-component>.component';'' and inside that same file add a line '<name-component>Component' as another item in the list of 'declarations' which is inside '@NgModule'", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="angular" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("add routes in angular", "1) execute 'ng new <app-name> --routing' 2) if you want a route for component <component-name> then add inside routes, in your file 'app-routing.module.ts' as another item in the array 'routes', the next code '{path: <path-name1>, <component-import-name1>}' for component <component-import-name1> and for any other component. 3) also in the 'app-routing.module.ts' file add 'import {<component-import-name1>} from '<component-route1>';' for <component-import-name1> and for any other component 4) at the end of 'app-routing.module.ts' file add 'export const routingComponents = [<component-import-name1>, <component-import-name1>... ];' fro all the imported components. 5) in 'app.module.ts' replace 'import {AppRoutingModule} from ''./app-routing.module'';' with 'import {AppRoutingModule, routingComponents} from ''./app-routing.module'';' 6) in 'app.module.ts', go to the array 'declarations' (which is inside '@NgModule') and add 'routingComponents' as another item of your array 'declarations'. 7) now you can go to 'localhost:<server-port>/<path-name1>' for your component and the same with the other component where you create them a route. 8) user router-link for an HTML element you want to use for redirecting, for example '<a router-link=''<path-name1>''>go to component1</a>' 9) besides router-link you can also add the tag 'routerLinkActive=<classes>' to specify the classes to use in the link after clicked.", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="angular" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("module util and inherit events", "We can use the module util to make a function or class to inherit events, check the next example: let event s= require(''events); let util = require('util'); let Person = function(name){this.name=name;} util.inherits(Person, events.EventEmitter); let james = new Person('james'); let mary = new Person('mary'); let ryu = new Person('ryu'); james.on('speak', function(msg){console.log(james.name + ' said: ' + msg);}); mary.on('speak', function(msg){console.log(mary.name + ' said: ' + msg);}); ryu.on('speak', function(msg){console.log(ryu.name + ' said: ' + msg);}); james.emit('speak', 'hey dudes'); mary.emit('speak', 'hi'); // this code will show in console 'james said: hey dudes' and in the next line 'mary said: hi'", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="node.js" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("read Stream", "streams are useful because sometimes we have to transfer a lot of information so instead of wait to transfer everything we can get access to the transferred part, to do this we can send information in chunks (pieces of data). To read a stream do the next: let fs = required('fs'); let myReadStream = fs.createReadStream(__dirname+'/text.txt', 'utf-8'); myReadStream.on('data', function(chunk){ console.log('new chunk received'); console.log(chunk); }); //in this way, for every chunk it shows in the terminal the message 'new chunk received' // and show the chunk obtained from the file. In this case, the file is a text in the current //directory and with name text.txt", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="node.js" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("write stream", "streams are useful because sometimes we have to transfer a lot of information so instead of wait to transfer everything we can get access to the transferred part, to do this we can send information in chunks (pieces of data). To write a stream do the next: let fs = required('fs'); let myReadStream = fs.createReadStream(__dirname+'/text.txt', 'utf-8'); let myWriteStream = fs.createWriteStream(__dirname+'/write.txt'); myReadStream.on('data', function(chunk){ console.log('new chunk received'); myWriteStream.write(chunk); }); //in this way, you copy the content of one file to another by chunks //for each chunk send and copied in the new file the terminal shows //the message 'new chunk received'", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="node.js" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));

For example, imaging sort countries by continent order by population, then using ROW_NUMBER() OVER with PARTITION BY you assign 1 to USA cause is the country with most population in north ameria, also 1 to nigeria cause the most population in Africa, etc. Use PARTITION BY this way: ROW_NUMBER() OVER(Partition by <criteria1> ORDER BY <criteria2>) as <alias>", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="SQL Server" and u0.email="oscarporras02@gmail.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("combination", "different from permutation, where order matters, in combination order doesn't matter. so 'a,b,c' is equal to 'a,c,b'. this also means that combinations of n elements in a list of n elements will be 1, since order doesn't matter there just one possibility to get n between n. What if you want k elements of n? (where k<n, dah!). Then use the next formula: !n/(!k*!(n-k)) for example, combinations of 3 elements between a group of 5, then: !5/(!3*!(5-3)) = 120/(6*2) = 10", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

Example: ax + by = c dx + ey = f x = | c b | | f e | _____ | a b | | d e | and y = | a c | | d f | _____ | a b | | d e | specific example: x - 2y = -3 3x + y = 5 x = |-3 -2| | 5 1 | -3+10 7 _____ = ______ = __ = 1 | 1 -2| 1 + 6 7 | 3 1 | and y = | 1 -3| | 3 5 | 5 + 9 14 _____ = _____ = ___ = 2 | 1 -2| 1 + 6 7 | 3 1 | solution: x=1 and y=2", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("inverse matrix", "Having a matrix A which is invertible (also known as non-single), in other words, a matrix which determinant is not zero, then the inverse matrix (expressed as A^(-1)) is such that: A*A^(-1) = I Where 'I' is the identity matrix. To find the inverse matrix of A you can begin to operate the matrix until you get the identity matrix, each operation you do in the A matrix also does it in an identity matrix, the final result of the identity matrix will be the inverse matrix. Example: |-3 1 | | 1 0 | | 5 0 | | 0 1 | | 5 0 | | 0 1 | |-3 1 | | 1 0 | | 1 0 | | 0 1/5| |-3 1 | | 1 0 | | 1 0 | | 0 1/5| | 0 1 | | 1 3/5| Therefore: inverse of: |-3 1 | | 5 0 | is: | 0 1/5| | 1 3/5| and: |-3 1 | * | 0 1/5| = | 1 0 | | 5 0 | | 1 3/5| | 0 1 |", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Matrix multiplication", "To multiply matrix A and B, the number of columns of matrix A must be equal to the number of rows in matrix B, then, for the number in m column and k row, multiple each n element of m column in matrix A with each n element of K row in matrix B. example: | 1 2 | * | 7 2 0 1 | | 5 6 | |-1 6 3 4 | | 7 9 | = element in column 0 row 0 will be = 1*7 + 2*(-1) = 5 element in column 0 row 2 will be = 7*7 + 9*(-1) = 40 element in column 1 row 2 will be = 7*2 + 9*6 = 68 The final solution for the multiplication will be: | 5 14 6 9 | |29 46 18 29| |40 68 27 43|", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("transpose matrix", "the transpose of a matrix A (expressed as A^(t)) is the matrix in which columns are equivalent to the rows of matrix A and in which rows are equivalent to A columns. As a result, the ij (i row, j column) element in matrix A will be in ji position in the transposed matrix, for each element in matrix A. Example: | 1 2 | | 3 4 | = A | 5 6 | | 1 3 5 | A^(t) = | 2 4 6 | ", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("cofactor matrix", "The cofactors matrix of A (also represented as cof(A)) is the matrix with the cofactors of ach element in the matrix. Example: For the element in position i row and j column, the cofactor will be: (-1^(i+j))*subMatrix where submatrix is the determinant of the matrix when excluding the elements in row I and column j. Complete example: | 1 2 3 | | 0 4 5 | | 1 0 6 | cofactor in position 0 row and 0 column: (-1^(0+0))*((4*6)-(5*0)) = 24 cofactor in position 0 row and 2 column: (-1^(0+2))*((0*0)-(4*1))=-4 cofactor in position 1 row and 2 column: (-1^(1+2))*((1*0)-(2*1))=2 Complete solution will be: |24 5 -4| |-12 3 2 | |-2 -5 4 | ", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

The adjunct matrix of A (expressed as adj(A)) is equal to the transpose of its cofactor matrix, since: adj(A) = cof(A)^(t) One of the practical uses of the adjunct matrix is to be used for calculating the inverse, this is because of the next rule: A^(-1)=(1/det(A))*adj(A)", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("cross product", "having two vectors, which passes through the origin, in a three-dimensional space, the cross product is the vector C which is perpendicular to A and B, and which has a magnitude equal to the area of the parallelogram made by A and B. To calculate this vector use the next formula: Having A = (Ai, Aj, Ak) and B = (Bi, Bj, Bk) i * | Aj Ak | | Bj Bk | - j * | Ai Ak | | Bi Bk | + k * | Ai Aj | | Bi Bj | Example: A = (0,2,0) B = (2,0,0) i * | 2 0 | | 0 0 | - j * | 0 0 | | 2 0 | + k * | 0 2 | | 2 0 | = 0i -0j + 4k", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("span", "In linear algebra, a span of a set of vectors is all the linear combination of that set of vectors. So to say that vector A is a span of vectors B and C means that A can be expressed as, AT LEAST, one linear combination of B and C. Example: let v = {(2,3),(1,2)} find if vector (19,3) is part of span v: 2x + y = 19 3x + 2y = 3 2x + y = 19 y = -51 x = 35 y = -51 Like there is at least one way to combine the vectors in v to generate (19,3) vector then this vector is part of the span v. Example 2: having v ={(1,3,2),(-1,2,-1),(-1,12,1)} find if vector (1,1,1) is part of span v x-y-z=1 3x+2y+12z=1 2x-y+z=1 x-y-z=1 3x+2y+12z=1 2x-y+z=1 x-y-z=1 0+5y+15z=-2 0+y+3z =-1 x-y-z=1 0+5y+15z=-2 0+0+0 =3 Since valid operations generate a contradiction in the last row, then there is not even one solution for the system and therefore the vector (1,1,1) is not in the span v. NOTE: if instead of 3, we had got 0 in the last column then the system would have infinite solutions, and in that case we would said that vector is part of the span.", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

To find the directional cosines use the next formula: cos(a) = vx/||v|| cos(b) = vy/||v|| cos(c) = vz/||v|| where ||v|| = (vx^2 + vy^2 + vz^2)^0.5 About the directional cosines there is an important constant really easy to deduce: cos(a)^2 + cos(b)^2 + cos(c)^2 = 1", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

It works in two steps: (a) [Base case:] Prove that P(a) is true. INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("inductive proof of fibonacci arithmetic formula", "proof that for all n>=1 we can get the Fibonacci number this way: 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^n | 1 - 5^0.5 |^n| Fn = -------- * | |----------------| - |----------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | we will use the principle of strong induction, so first we proof the first two cases, then we proof every case is true. 1) if n=1 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^1 | 1 - 5^0.5 |^1| F(1)= -------- * | |----------------| - |----------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | 2 * 5^0.5 Fn = ------------- = 1 2 * 5^0.5 2) if n=2 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^2 | 1 - 5^0.5 |^2| F(2)= -------- * | |----------------| - |----------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | 4 * 5^0.5 Fn = ------------- = 1 4 * 5^0.5 3) general case F(n+1) = Fn + F(n-1) 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^n | 1 - 5^0.5 |^n| -------- * | |----------------| - |----------------| | + 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^(n-1) | 1 - 5^0.5 |^(n-1)| -------- * | |----------------| - |----------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | = 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^n | 1 + 5^0.5 |^(n-1)| -------- * | |----------------| + |----------------| | - 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | 1 | | 1 - 5^0.5 |^n | 1 - 5^0.5 |^(n-1)| -------- * | |----------------| + |----------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | | <by golden ratio recurrence the previous is equal to> 1 | | 1 + 5^0.5 |^(n+1) | 1 - 5^0.5 |^(n+1)| Fn = -------- * | |----------------| - |---------------| | 5^0.5 | | 2 | | 2 | |", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="mathematics" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

Return output sorted by N*/ select b.N, (case when P is null then 'Root' when exists(select * from BST where p=b.N) then 'Inner' else 'Leaf' end) as q from BST as b order by b.N", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("company hierarchy", "/* Having the next tables (mutually related) and its columns: company: int company_code, string founder lead_manager: int lead_manager_code, int company_code senior_manager: int senior_manager_code, int lead_manager_code manager: manager_code, int senior_manager_code employee: int employee_code, int manager_code show for each row a company code, its founder and its total of lead managers, total of senior manager, total of managers and total of employees. Order by company code*/ select c.company_code, c.founder, count(distinct lm.lead_manager_code), count(distinct sm.senior_manager_code), count(distinct m.manager_code), count(distinct e.employee_code) from company as c inner join lead_manager as lm on c.company_code=lm.company_code inner join senior_manager as sm on lm.lead_manager_code=sm.lead_manager_code inner join manager as m on sm.senior_manager_code=m.senior_manager_code inner join employee as e on m.manager_code=e.manager_code group by c.company_code, c.founder order by company_code;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("find median", "/*having the table STATION with column LAT_N which is a double, return the median value of LAT_N*/ declare @total int; set @total = (select count(*) from station); with sorted_lat as (select lat_n, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(ORDER BY lat_n) as n from station) select top 1 case when @total%2=0 then cast(round(((select top 1 lat_n*1.0 from sorted_lat where n=@total/2)+(select top 1 lat_n*1.0 from sorted_lat where n-1=@total/2))/2,4) as decimal(18,4)) else cast(round((select top 1 lat_n from sorted_lat where n-1=@total/2),4) as decimal(18,4)) end from sorted_lat;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

Note: CITY.CountryCode and COUNTRY.Code are matching key columns.*/ select co.continent, avg(ci.population) from city as ci inner join country as co on ci.countrycode=co.code group by co.continent;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("the report", "/* having the next tables (with its columns) students: id, name, marks grades: grade, min_mark, max_mark and grades has the next rows: 1,0,9 2,10,19 3,20,29 4,30,39 5,40,49 6,50,59 7,60,69 8,70,79 9,80,89 10,90,100 Ketty gives Eve a task to generate a report containing three columns: Name, Grade and Mark. Ketty doesn't want the NAMES of those students who received a grade lower than 8. The report must be in descending order by grade -- i.e. higher grades are entered first. If there is more than one student with the same grade (8-10) assigned to them, order those particular students by their name alphabetically. Finally, if the grade is lower than 8, use 'NULL' as their name and list them by their grades in descending order. If there is more than one student with the same grade (1-7) assigned to them, order those particular students by their marks in ascending order. */ select name, grade, marks from (select name, grade, marks, val, n from (select s.name, g.grade, s.marks, 1 as val, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(ORDER BY g.grade desc, s.name) as n from students as s inner join grades as g on s.marks<=g.max_mark and s.marks>=g.min_mark where s.marks>=70) as high union select name, grade, marks, val, n from (select 'NULL' as name, g.grade, s.marks, 2 as val, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(ORDER BY g.grade desc, s.marks) as n from students as s inner join grades as g on s.marks<=g.max_mark and s.marks>=g.min_mark where s.marks<70) as low) as new_query order by val, n;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Top Competitors", "/*having the next tables hackers: hacker_id, name challenges: challenge_id, hacker_id, difficulty_level difficulty: difficulty_level, score submissions: submission_id, hacker_id, challenge_id, score A hacker submits challenges, each challenge has a difficulty (and a creator). Return the id and name of hackers who get more than 1 full score. Order your output in descending order by the total number of challenges in which the hacker earned a full score. If more than one hacker received full scores in same number of challenges, then sort them by ascending hacker_id.*/ select h.hacker_id, h.name from hackers as h inner join submissions as s on h.hacker_id=s.hacker_id inner join challenges as c on c.challenge_id=s.challenge_id inner join difficulty as d on c.difficulty_level = d.difficulty_level where d.score=s.score group by h.hacker_id, h.name having count(*)>1 order by count(*) desc, h.hacker_id;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

Write a query to print the id, age, coins_needed, and power of the wands, sorted in order of descending power. If more than one wand has the same power, sort the result in order of descending age. */ with b as (select wp.age, w.power, min(coins_needed) as cn from wands as w inner join wands_property as wp on w.code = wp.code where wp.is_evil=0 group by wp.age, w.power), t as (select w.id, wp.age, w.power, w.coins_needed from wands as w inner join wands_property as wp on w.code = wp.code) select t.id, t.age, t.coins_needed, t.power from b inner join t on b.age=t.age and b.power=t.power and b.cn=t.coins_needed order by t.power desc, t.age desc;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Contest Leaderboard", "/* having the next tables hackers: hacker_id, name submissions: submission_id, hacker_id, challenge_id, score print the hacker_id, name and total score of each hacker. The total score is the sum of the max score obtained by each hacker in each challenge. Exclude when total score equals 0. Order by descending total_score. If more than one hacker achieved the same total score, then sort the result by ascending hacker_id. */ with m as (select s.hacker_id, h.name, s.challenge_id, max(s.score) as best from hackers as h inner join submissions as s on h.hacker_id=s.hacker_id group by s.hacker_id, h.name, s.challenge_id having max(s.score)>0) select hacker_id, name, sum(best) from m group by hacker_id, name order by sum(best) desc, hacker_id;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("SQL Project Planning", "/* You are given a table, Projects, containing three columns: Task_ID, Start_Date and End_Date. It is guaranteed that the difference between the End_Date and the Start_Date is equal to 1 day for each row in the table. If the End_Date of the tasks are consecutive, then they are part of the same project. Samantha is interested in finding the total number of different projects completed. Write a query to output the start and end dates of projects listed by the number of days it took to complete the project in ascending order. If there is more than one project that have the same number of completion days, then order by the start date of the project. */ with sp as (select p0.start_date, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(ORDER BY start_date) as n from projects as p0 where not exists(select * from projects as p1 where p1.end_date=p0.start_date)), ep as (select p0.end_date, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(ORDER BY end_date) as n from projects as p0 where not exists(select * from projects as p1 where p1.start_date=p0.end_date)) select sp.start_date, ep.end_date from sp inner join ep on sp.n=ep.n order by DATEDIFF(day, sp.start_date, ep.end_date), sp.start_date;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Placements", "/*You are given three tables: Students, Friends and Packages. Students contains two columns: ID and Name. Friends contains two columns: ID and Friend_ID (ID of the ONLY best friend). Packages contains two columns: ID and Salary (offered salary in $ thousands per month). Write a query to output the names of those students whose best friends got offered a higher salary than them. Names must be ordered by the salary amount offered to the best friends. It is guaranteed that no two students got same salary offer.*/ select s0.name from friends as f inner join students as s0 on f.id=s0.id inner join students as s1 on f.friend_id=s1.id inner join packages as p0 on s0.id=p0.id inner join packages as p1 on s1.id=p1.id where p0.salary<p1.salary order by p1.salary;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Symmetric Pairs", "/*You are given a table, Functions, containing two columns: X and Y. Two pairs (X1, Y1) and (X2, Y2) are said to be symmetric pairs if X1 = Y2 and X2 = Y1. Write a query to output all such symmetric pairs in ascending order by the value of X. List the rows such that X1 ≤ Y1.*/ with point as (select x, y, ROW_NUMBER() over(order by x) as id from functions), solution as (select (SELECT MIN(v) FROM (VALUES (p1.x),(p1.y)) as val(v)) as x1, (SELECT MAX(v) FROM (VALUES (p1.x),(p1.y)) as val(v)) as y1 from point as p1 inner join point as p2 on p1.x=p2.y and p1.y=p2.x and p1.id<p2.id) select x1, y1 from solution order by x1;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Draw The Triangle 1", "/* P(R) represents a pattern drawn by Julia in R rows. The following pattern represents P(5): * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Write a query to print the pattern P(20). */ declare @number int; set @number = 20; declare @ast varchar(250); set @ast = ''; WHILE @number > 0 BEGIN /*minus 1 cause by default any varchar remove blank spaces at the end*/ while len(@ast)<@number*2-1 begin set @ast= concat(@ast, '* '); end; select @ast; set @ast = ''; SET @number = @number - 1; END;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));

The following pattern represents P(5): * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * Write a query to print the pattern P(20). */ declare @number int; set @number=1; declare @ast varchar(250); set @ast=''; while @number<=20 begin set @ast = concat(@ast, '* '); select @ast; set @number = @number +1; end;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("print prime numbers", "/*Write a query to print all prime numbers less than or equal to 1000. Print your result on a single line, and use the ampersand () character as your separator (instead of a space). For example, the output for all prime numbers would be:*/ DECLARE @primes TABLE (num INT); DECLARE @noprimes TABLE (num INT); declare @candidate int; declare @multi int; Declare @val Varchar(8000); set @candidate = 2; while @candidate<=1000 begin if not exists(select num from @noprimes where num=@candidate) begin insert into @primes select @candidate; set @multi = @candidate*2; while @multi<=1000 begin insert into @noprimes select @multi; set @multi = @multi + @candidate; end end set @candidate = @candidate +1; end; select @val = coalesce(@val+'&'+cast(num as varchar(3)), concat('',num)) from @primes; select @val;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("Interviews", "/*Samantha interviews many candidates from different colleges using coding challenges and contests. Write a query to print the contest_id, hacker_id, name, and the sums of total_submissions, total_accepted_submissions, total_views, and total_unique_views for each contest sorted by contest_id. Exclude the contest from the result if all four sums are 0. contests: contest_id, hacker_id, name colleges: college_id, contest_id challenges: challenge_id, college_id view_stats: challenge_id, total_views, total_unique_views submission_stats: challenge_id, total_submissions, total_accepted_submissions note: each challenge has many view_stats, each challenge has many submission_stats */ with q1 as (select con.contest_id, con.hacker_id, con.name, sum(vie.total_views) as tv, sum(vie.total_unique_views) as uv from contests as con inner join colleges as col on con.contest_id = col.contest_id inner join challenges as cha on col.college_id=cha.college_id inner join view_stats as vie on cha.challenge_id = vie.challenge_id group by con.contest_id, con.hacker_id, con.name), q2 as (select con.contest_id, con.hacker_id, con.name, sum(sub.total_submissions) as ts, sum(sub.total_accepted_submissions) as tas from contests as con inner join colleges as col on con.contest_id = col.contest_id inner join challenges as cha on col.college_id=cha.college_id inner join submission_stats as sub on cha.challenge_id = sub.challenge_id group by con.contest_id, con.hacker_id, con.name) select q1.contest_id, q1.hacker_id, q1.name, q2.ts, q2.tas, q1.tv, q1.uv from q1 inner join q2 on q1.contest_id=q2.contest_id order by q1.contest_id;", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
INSERT INTO "words" ("word", "translation", "created_at", "updated_at", "user_id", "techno_id") VALUES ("15 Days of Learning SQL", "/*Julia conducted a days of learning SQL contest. The start date of the contest was March 01, 2016 and the end date was March 15, 2016. Write a query to print total number of unique hackers who made at least submission each day (submissions each day until first day of the contest, until second day, etc), and find the hacker_id and name of the hacker who made maximum number of submissions each day. If more than one such hacker has a maximum number of submissions, print the lowest hacker_id. The query should print this information for each day of the contest, sorted by the date.*/ DECLARE @dates TABLE (day date); declare @days date set @days = '2016-03-01'; while @days<='2016-03-15' begin insert into @dates select @days; set @days = DATEADD(day, 1, @days); end; with q1 as (select d.day, (select count(distinct s1.hacker_id) from submissions as s1 where (select count(distinct s2.submission_date) from submissions as s2 where s1.hacker_id=s2.hacker_id and s2.submission_date<=d.day)=datediff(day, '2016-03-01', d.day)+1 ) as total from @dates as d order by d.day OFFSET 0 ROWS), q2 as (select submission_date, total, hacker_id, name from (select submission_date, total, hacker_id, name, ROW_NUMBER() OVER(partition by q1.submission_date ORDER BY total desc, q1.hacker_id) as sort from (select s1.submission_date, s1.hacker_id, count(s1.hacker_id) as total, h1.name from submissions as s1 inner join hackers as h1 on s1.hacker_id=h1.hacker_id group by s1.submission_date, s1.hacker_id, h1.name) as q1) as q2 where sort=1) select q1.day, q1.total, q2.hacker_id, q2.name from q1 inner join q2 on q1.day=q2.submission_date", date("now"), date("now"), (select id from users where email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1), (select t0.id from technos as t0 inner join users as u0 on t0.user_id=u0.id where t0.techno_name="sql queries" and u0.email="oscarrussi@outlook.com" limit 1));
